message: This event is an opportunity for constituents to discuss issues that matter to them directly with Congressman Cartwright.    This event is open to the public. RSVPs are not required.   If you need more information please call our office 570-341-1050.
I guess it's not flashy, but this is the kind of common sense, money-saving legislation I like to write.

Barack Obama awarded Joe Biden the Presidential Medal of Freedom. I agree with President Obama and am honored to have had the privilege of serving for the past four years under one of "the best vice presidents America has ever had." Congratulations to a "scrappy kid from Scranton" who has made us proud in his service to America.

Today, we honor the enduring and powerful legacy of Martin Luther King, Jr. As we celebrate Dr. King’s birthday, we must continue to work together to ensure that opportunities are available to everyone, regardless of race or ethnicity.  I encourage all Americans to continue to strive until Dr. King’s vision is finally realized.

Today I received my subcommittee assignments for the House Committee on Appropriations.  I will serve on the Commerce, Justice, and Science Subcommittee and the Financial Services and General Government Subcommittee.  I intend to use my role on these subcommittees to help spur economic growth in the 17th congressional district. http://cartwright.house.gov/media-center/press-releases/rep-cartwright-announces-subcommittee-assignments-for-the-house

Not in criticism of those taking another approach, but out of respect for the peaceful transfer of power, our American tradition, I am attending the inauguration.  I also remember that most of my Republican colleagues attended President Obama's, and I mean to return the gesture.
In meetings and calls, I have done my best to add my voice to those of local legislators asking DOC Secretary Wetzel not to close prisons in our area.  We need Harrisburg to work with Gov. Wolf.

I join my fellow Lehigh Valley Congressman, Charlie Dent (R-PA), in urging President Donald Trump to rethink his ill-conceived, discriminatory and dangerous executive order banning Muslim travel to this country.  Our national devotion to religious freedom and tolerance is not Republican or Democratic.  It's American.

It was my pleasure to present James (Jimmy) Kelleher, a rising professional boxer now based in Scranton, with a Congressional Record at the United Way of the Lehigh Valley TeenWorks dinner. I applaud TeenWorks for their success encouraging so many young people to help those in need and improve communities. So nice to see so many in attendance including Gregg Potter, Gabbi Brescia, and Dana Emswiler.

Today, Tom Marino (R-PA) and I saw our bill, HR 560, pass unanimously out of the U.S. House of Representatives. This bill will open up PA Route 209 to limited, local commercial traffic under a permitting system for 5 years.  It will ease congestion and make life easier for small businesses in and around the Delaware Water Gap.

Regrettably, Reps. Steve King (R-IA) and Joe Wilson (R-SC) today introduced a bill that would rewrite the National Labor Relations Act to repeal the requirement that all employees in a unionized workplace pay union dues, given that the union negotiates for all. I oppose this legislation.  I believe the NLRA reached the proper balance, that changing it like this is a direct attack on union finances, and that it will lead to lower wages for working people.

I don't get a vote on this, but I would urge Senators not to rubber-stamp this nomination. Ms. DeVos seems like a nice person, but has shown that standing up for American public education is not a core value for her. She has a penchant for pulling public money out of public schools. She is unfamiliar with federal laws guaranteeing quality and appropriate education for all. We need a Secretary who understands that quality public education for all is the only way we can give all of our citizens an actual opportunity to succeed.

This was astonishing.  Senate Rule 19 prohibits any disparaging remarks about another Senator even if the disparaging statements are true.  So Mitch McConnell used that to prevent Sen. Warren from discussing legitimate questions about Alabama Sen. Jeff Sessions' history of racial discrimination, even as he is being considered to be the top law enforcer in our nation.

A lot of my Republican friends do care about clean water and clean air and taking care of the earth that God gave us. Scott Pruitt is not one of them.  Pruitt has an extreme anti-conservation agenda, and refuses to reveal his ties to polluters.  He's just not the right choice to stand up for sensible protections of our environment.
I am committed to preserving affordable health care for hard-working citizens, seniors, and children.
NA

I wanted to share with you this brief but characteristically uplifting video from my friend from across the river, U.S. Senator Cory Booker, with Frederick Douglass as backdrop, in the middle of Black History Month.

Please join me this week for a town hall!  The town hall will be held on Wednesday, February 22, 2017 from 6:30 p.m. to 7:30 p.m. at the Dickson City Borough Building located at 901 Enterprise Street, Dickson City, PA 18519.  The event is open to the public. No RSVPs are required.
I thank the Humane Society of the United States for taking the lead in demanding that the USDA restore animal abuse and puppy mill information to its website, which was abruptly deleted this month.

I have high hopes for highly decorated Lt.Gen. H.R. McMaster as our National Security Advisor. His book, "Dereliction of Duty," is all about speaking truth to power, how the military failed LBJ in not being honest about the difficulty of prevailing in Vietnam. This is what we need now.

At the special request of Ranking Member Elijah Cummings, I have decided to continue my work on the House Oversight and Government Reform Committee (OGR), in addition to my duties on the House Appropriations Committee. Finding and eradicating government waste, fraud and abuse is our major focus on OGR.  http://cartwright.house.gov/media-center/press-releases/rep-cartwright-rejoins-house-oversight-and-government-reform-committee
Thanks to everyone who came out and participated in our town hall meeting last night in Dickson City.  I've done about 15 of these, and this was the biggest turnout so far!  We had a good discussion.

I had the honor of presenting the Bronze Star Medal to the adult children of the late U.S. Army Air Corps Sgt. John J Ostrum for his heroics during the attack on Pearl Harbor, December 7, 1941. Under enemy strafing fire, Sgt Ostrum saved lives by moving oil drums away from raging fires.

I’m proud to receive a National Environmental Scorecard rating of 100% from the League of Conservation Voters. I will continue to fight for policies that combat climate change, keep our water clean, protect our air quality, and protect our nation’s natural resources.   https://twitter.com/LCVoters/status/834855446691315715

Honoring Black History Month at the Monroe County NAACP Annual Luncheon. Enjoyed the speakers, African American Artwork, and the dancers from the "Eleve Dance Theatre". Thank you Thomas and Sharone Jones for allowing me to say a few words at this beautiful celebration.

It was an honor to present Thomas Williams with a Congressional Record for his federal and community service. Mr. Williams served as an aide to former Congressman Paul Kanjorski and before retiring he was the State Director of the U.S. Department of Agriculture Rural Development for Pennsylvania appointed by President Obama. I want to wish Tom all the best in his retirement.

Michelle LaCroix of Scranton was my guest last evening to the President’s Joint Address to Congress.  Michelle is a survivor of the opioid epidemic.  Because of the Affordable Care Act, she was able to stay on her parents’ health insurance and receive the care she needed. Opioid addiction devastates families from all walks of life in Pennsylvania and across the country. I thank Michelle for joining me and sharing her story.
I got my legislative Report Card for the 114th Congress (2015-16).  You can see the whole thing at govtrack.us.  More work to do!

In 1971, when I was 10, my public school teacher Isabel Daniels decided I was causing so much trouble in class that I must be given more work to do. She handed me a copy of The Hobbit and said I had to read it. It has led to a lifetime love of reading. Thank you, Miss Daniels! Today we celebrate National Education Association's "Read Across America". Motivating children to read is an important factor in student achievement, research has shown that children who spend more time reading do better in school.
I am inviting you to have coffee with me; come and discuss the issues that are important to you. Hope to see you in Brodheadsville on Tuesday, March 14th.

International Women's Day celebrates the power of women, their courage, and persistence to fight for what they believe in and deserve. In 1917, Representative Jeannette Rankin of Montana was the first woman elected to Congress.  We celebrate and honor all women today.
NA
"Coffee with your Congressman" in Brodheadsville has been postponed due to inclement weather forecast. Please be careful and stay safe in these next couple of days of bad weather.

The last couple of days in Northeastern Pennsylvania have not been easy. Let us remember our First Responders who are out there on a daily basis helping, protecting, and doing their best to serve us all. Please be careful and stay safe.

The White House's budget proposes completely eliminating funding for public TV, legal services for the poor, and the special extra economic development funding we get for our rural northeastern Pennsylvania counties.  Here is a more complete list of the cuts, most of which would damage our area and our nation.
I enjoyed working with Senator Bill Cassidy last year to pass our MEGABYTE Act, which will reduce wasteful technology spending. NASA has already saved taxpayers $100 million.
This event is an opportunity for constituents to discuss issues that matter to them directly with Congressman Cartwright. For more information please call 570-341-1050.

The House GOP plan to "repeal and replace" the ACA is a bad bill.  It throws 60,000 of my constituents off their coverage, it costs a lot more for everyone aged 50-64, and it endangers our community hospitals.

An hour ago, Speaker Ryan abruptly withdrew the GOP-only rewrite of national healthcare law.  My hope is that this will force us all to work together and improve American healthcare so it works better for everyone.

It was great to join Mayor Dan Lello, Council President Stanley Knick, Senator John Blake, Representative and Mrs. Mike Carroll, Judge and Mrs. Fred Pierantoni, Chairman Bob Price, and many others at the Dupont VFW for the Dupont Centennial Banquet last night. Special congrats to Margaret Milewski, 101, who got the Key to Dupont!

Please join me for a public town hall meeting to discuss the issues that matter to you. The town hall will be held in the Scheller Center at Lehigh Carbon Community College. For questions please call: (570) 341-1050.  This event is free and open to the public.
I think it makes more sense to require internet service providers to ask your permission before they are allowed to sell your personal information.  So, I voted "no" on this bill this afternoon.

Great to meet with NEPA and PA-17 residents Becky Jacobs, Michelle Luchetti, Phyllis Gallagher, and Kady Luchetti today. I'm grateful for all of their hard work advocating to end Alzheimer's.   This afternoon, Phyllis, of Schuylkill County, testified in front of the Senate Special Committee on Aging about her experiences as an Early-Onset Alzheimer's caregiver. Thank you, Phyllis, for sharing your story.

I am proud to be the lead Democrat on the RECLAIM Act, which would pump $1 billion into Abandoned Mine Lands reclamation in the former coal regions, a lot of which are in our district in Pennsylvania.  Pictured:  McDade Park, on reclaimed mine land south of Scranton.  Thanks for this Citizens' Voice editorial this week.

Women deserve equal pay for equal work. The Equal Pay Act was signed into law 54 years ago today, but women's wages continue to lag behind those of their male colleagues. Pay inequity doesn’t just affect women – it also affects children, working families, and our entire economy.

It was a delight for me to have Easton's terrific Mayor Sal Panto join us for an Appropriations Committee lunch in Washington today.  The Mayor was in town to testify before the House Energy & Commerce subcommittee on the Environment on Easton's successful Simon Silk Mill brownfields redevelopment project and to represent the National League of Cities in his testimony on brownfields.
NA

This week my colleagues and I introduced legislation to prevent coal companies from unfairly denying benefits to miners. Miners risked their health and safety to reach for financial security for their families, yet too many miners are wrongfully denied the benefits they deserve. Our country became great on the backs of hard-working miners - we should not be turning our backs on them now. https://instagram.com/p/BSl7arUAiB8/
This week, colleagues in the U.S. House joined me in introducing bills to repeal clean water and clean air loopholes for the oil and gas industry. Every other industry complies with these laws.

America strong.  U.S. Army Staff Sgt. Earl Granville (ret.), of Carbondale, who lost his leg to a roadside bomb during his third deployment with the 109th PA National Guard in Afghanistan in 2008, and then his twin brother, Staff Sgt. Joseph Granville in 2010, to combat-veteran suicide, just keeps on making everyone in northeastern Pennsylvania proud.

National Park Week is America's largest celebration of national heritage. Discover all there is to see and do in your national parks https://findyourpark.com/ and see which parks wave their entrance fees on nationally designated fee free dates https://www.nps.gov/.

I was humbled to have Action Together NEPA come to my office with thank you cards for the work I have been doing on behalf PA-17 and Northeastern Pennsylvania. We should all continue to fight for what we believe in; I will continue to do what I believe is right for all Pennsylvanians.

The very first Earth Day was celebrated April 22, 1970. Americans from all over the world celebrate earth day with great enthusiasm; events worldwide bring awareness to the importance in keeping our planet healthy and clean.

In addition to Earth Day, it's also Opening Day for Little League, in Moosic and also Pittston Township. Here at Mike Felter Field in Moosic to see his grandson is former Army Drill Sgt. Ronnie Mills, 101st Airborne, Vietnam 1969-70, winner of the Bronze Star and Combat Infantryman's Badge, and his friendly 4-month old Chihuahua, Gibbs!
Today I was happy to attend the Eagle Scout Court of Honor of Matthew W. Cully, Troop 102, Saylorsburg. Congratulations, Matthew!  With State Sen. Mario Scavello.

I have been a committed advocate for the continuation of the federal Land and Water Conservation Fund, and its support for expanding the Cherry Valley National Wildlife Refuge along the Kittatinny Ridge in Northampton County, and I appreciate the bipartisan support from Sens. Bob Casey and Pat Toomey.

We had two full and busy district work weeks with town hall meetings and coffee events throughout my district. As part of my job, I am always happy to listen to concerns and questions from my constituents. It is important to me that I do the job I was elected to do, and I am proud to serve the hard working people of Northeastern Pennsylvania.

We appear to have an agreement to fund the government through September 30.  I am happy to report that we have prevailed in the House Appropriations Committee in securing more than a billion dollars to deliver permanent health benefits for the thousands of coal miners and their families who stood to lose their health benefits this month, increases in medical research, science funding, and money to fight the opioid epidemic. It also preserves Pell grants, 99% of EPA funding, and many other popular domestic programs.

I was happy to stop and visit with the Easton Fire Department after just being awarded the Assistance to Firefighters Grant (AFG). I am pleased to help and assist with this type of grant to ensure that firefighters have the resources they need to protect themselves and the community. Thank you Fire Chief John Bast, Deputy Chief Kevin Arnold, Mayor Sal Panto, Councilman Peter Melan, and City Administrator Luis Campos for joining me.

I am happy to report that the Omnibus bill to fund the federal government through September 30 includes my legislation to give a 2.1% raise to our faithful Wage Grade employees at Tobyhanna Army Depot, all 1,800 of them.  The bill passed the House today, 309-118.
WBRE News at one of the best manufacturing facilities in PA.  It's a great -- world renowned -- product, and a wonderful success story.

I voted no on the latest version of the American Health Care Act.  This bill would push more hospitals out of business by pushing people out of their current health care coverage. Eliminating the Affordable Care Act’s Medicaid expansion, which extended coverage to over 700,000 Pennsylvanians, will swell the number of people who cannot pay their hospital bills. These costs will fall on the shoulders of our community hospitals, and many of them will face closure.  Americans with pre-existing conditions would be denied health coverage or forced to pay higher premiums.  And Americans between the ages of 50-64 will pay premiums five times higher than what others pay for health coverage under the replacement bill.  That’s thousands of additional dollars annually.  Instead of enacting this ill-advised legislation, Democrats and Republicans should work together to improve the ACA.

I approve of the decision, by the Deputy Attorney General, to appoint former FBI Director Robert Mueller as special counsel in charge of the Russia probe. I first met Bob Mueller 4 years ago, and found him to be a serious and committed lawman. He has an admirable military service record in both the USMC and the Army Rangers, and an impressive academic background. I feel that Mueller will take a fearless approach to the investigation, and follow the facts wherever they take him.
This week is #NationalPoliceWeek. Please join me in thanking those who risk their lives to keep our communities safe.

This week I celebrate and recognize the men and women of our nation's emergency medical services (EMS) for their important contributions in safeguarding the health, safety, and well being of their communities.
I am proud to be part of the bipartisan team leading this effort to beef up employment rights for active duty military members.

Last year, the federal Department of Commerce's  Manufacturing Extension Partnership helped grow and sustain over 86,000 family-sustaining manufacturing jobs in this country. The current administration's budget proposes eliminating federal funding for the MEP. This week, Commerce Secretary Wilbur Ross told me cutting spending is more important. I cannot support that kind of penny-wise, pound-foolish thinking.

This week I joined a small Congressional delegation trip to the Tomb of the Unknown Soldier at Arlington National Cemetery, where we watched the changing of the guard and lay a wreath at the Tomb.  Happy Memorial Day, everyone, and take a moment to remember those who died for our freedom.
Proud to support our brave firefighters in Schuylkill County and throughout the 17th District.

I was honored to break ground with Gov. Tom Wolf and Rep. Aaron Kaufer on the West Pittston Community Garden, tour the new streetscape and flip the switch for the new street lamps. The teamwork among volunteers, borough residents and officials have helped West Pittston in its continuing recovery from the devastating flood six years ago.

Today marks the 73rd anniversary of D-Day. Allied troops joined forces to launch an audacious attack on the beaches of Normandy. On this anniversary day, let us remember the veterans of our "Greatest Generation" not only during World War II, but also before and after.

Today, I spoke on the House floor in opposition to the Wrong Choice Act. The Wrong Choice Act takes away provisions that rein in irresponsible pay to executives, dismantles consumer protections, eliminates transparency, and puts Americans in danger of taxpayer-funded bailouts.
I was happy to announce a federal grant of $250,000 to help grow jobs in Wilkes-Barre.

I am happy to announce that my bill, the Streamlining Energy Efficiency for Schools Act, unanimously passed the House this evening. This is a commonsense, no-cost bill that improves energy efficiency in schools.  This picture was taken at Nazareth Area Middle School, which has an array of solar panels on its building. I look forward to working with my colleagues to help advance this legislation in the Senate, so more schools have opportunities to pursue energy efficient upgrades.     http://cartwright.house.gov/media-center/press-releases/house-unanimously-passes-cartwright-and-welch-bill-to-improve-energy
Please send out your thoughts and prayers for my colleague Steve Scalise (R-Louisiana) and the Capitol Police officers and staffers who were hit in this morning's shooting.

This Pride Month, I recognize and honor the LGBT Americans who strive to build a more just society for all. Now more than ever, we should join together in support of one another, and know I stand with you in the fight for full equality and justice. Today and everyday we celebrate the diversity LGBT Americans bring to our communities.

Attending the Congressional Baseball Game this year, to show solidarity with all my fellow members. Dems lead 7-2, top of the 4th!  The brave soul diving into home plate at the end is freshman U.S. Rep. Jimmy Panetta (D-CA20).

As a member of the House Appropriations Committee, I can report that we have completed the first of our 12 funding bills for 2018, the VA and Military Construction bill. I am glad to say it provides robust funding for items I have been pushing:  suicide prevention, opioid addiction treatment, housing for homeless vets, and others.

Are you a high school student interested in showcasing your art? Congressman Matt Cartwright encourages all high school students from his district to submit their favorite work. Each spring, the US House of Representatives sponsors a nationwide high school art competition. Winners from each Congressional District will be displayed for one year in the Capitol.  Submission deadline for artwork is April 27, 2017.  Please contact your high school or our office for more information 570-341-1050.

I was glad I was able to make a wonderful dinner in Primrose earlier this month to pay tribute to the Honorable Joseph F. McCloskey, whose contributions to Pennsylvania justice and his community have been immense. After a successful legal career, Judge McCloskey served 22 years on the bench, including 7 years as President Judge of the Schuylkill County Common Pleas Court, and 12 years as a Senior Judge of the Commonwealth Court of Pennsylvania. Photo credit: Judy Muldowney
Did you know that early detection is the key in managing scoliosis?  June is Scoliosis Awareness Month. Check out srs.org.  Thanks Patricia Nestor!
I am proud to support federal grants which allow our firefighters to purchase the needed equipment to better prepare them and enhance public safety throughout the 17th District.
It's a pleasure to announce $3.4 million in new federal money coming to Scranton, for the medical school, one of our gems.

First responders put their lives on the line protecting families and communities every day but they can’t do their job without resources. That’s why I will continue to support our nation’s firefighters in every way that I can.

I am happy to support the National Endowment of the Arts grants. This funding helps The Scranton Shakespeare Festival provide opportunities to the community to engage in the arts and makes our lives richer.  Reserve your free tickets www.scrantonshakes.com

I am very proud to be serving on the U.S. House Appropriations Committee, where a lot of good, bipartisan work gets done.  This week we -- Republicans and Democrats -- came together to support having a real debate on Congress's role in authorizing military actions.  I believe Congress should stop abdicating its responsibilities in this area.
Announcing an additional $3.3 million in federal funds coming to Scranton, for the Wright Center for Graduate Medical Education.

Let us celebrate the birth of American independence. "We hold these truths to be sacred and undeniable; that all men are created equal and independent, that from the equal creation they derive rights inherent and unalienable, among which are the preservation of life, liberty, and the pursuit of happiness." - Thomas Jefferson.

Great fun attending the NEPA Philharmonic and fireworks show at Kirby Park in Kingston tonight. It was my pleasure to meet and give a shout-out to Bob Brodhead, 93, of Wilkes-Barre, a World War II Army veteran who served in Normandy and the Northern European theater as a PFC doing anti-aircraft duty. Happy Independence Day!
I was happy to announce a federal grant of $99,237 coming to Coaldale, Schuylkill County, for St. Luke's Miner's Memorial to help improve the quality of essential health care services.

When Congress works together, we can forward legislation that works for all Americans. I’m proud to be the lead Democrat on the bipartisan RECLAIM Act, which would fast-track $1 billion in available funding to revitalize coal communities.

Last night at the St. Patrick's church picnic I was honored to meet World War II Purple Heart veteran Gene Passarella, 92, of West Scranton.  Gene was a corporal with Gen. George S. Patton's Third Army, landing at Normandy on D+5, fighting through the hedgerows of northern France and into Belgium, where he was wounded in the right shin.  Gene and his wife, Louise, are celebrating 65 years of marriage this year.

Happy to be asked to participate in the first "SPEAK OUT" in Scranton against the Senate's Better Care Reconciliation Act. Communities leaders and families speaking out against the health care plan which will result in less coverage, higher costs, and more people uninsured. Thank you Marlee Stefanelli, Action Together NEPA, and everyone who came out last night; I stand with you and will continue to do all I can to make sure everyone has access to and can afford quality health care.

Proud to announce a $3,057,279 grant to Child Development Inc. of Schuylkill County. Early childhood education provides children with the tools they need to succeed in and out of the classroom; I will continue to support similar funding going forward.
In addition to our formal town hall events, we like to do more informal coffees to hear from you.  Come to one!
Do you think it's important for Members of Congress to have Town Halls and Coffee events? What's your opinion?  Follow WBRE|WYOU|PAHomepage Eyewitness News www.pahomepage.com

I'm proud to join the Climate Solutions Caucus to explore bipartisan solutions for fighting climate change. In order to join the caucus, members must pair with a member from across the aisle. I am pleased to join with my colleague, Rep. Leonard Lance (R-NJ-07).  https://cartwright.house.gov/media-center/press-releases/rep-cartwright-joins-bipartisan-caucus-to-advance-climate-solutions

Happy to tour the renovations and speak with veterans at the Gino J. Merli Veterans' Center in Scranton today; the announcement of federal funds this week provides the help needed to pay for the improvements. I was honored to thank Bill Clark U.S. Army 101st Airborne, Vietnam War and Stan Exeter Navy, Korean War for their service, we owe a debt of gratitude to all Veterans who serve our great nation.

Congratulations to Bailey Piechota from Pittston Area High School for being named PA-17th District's winner of the 2017 Congressional Art Competition. Bailey's charcoal drawing "Little Things" now hangs in the Cannon Tunnel to the U.S. Capitol; I commend all the student artists who submitted their work and celebrate the artistic talent of these students.
Announcing $4,297,661 in federal funding on its way to Scranton, for the terrific Head Start program.

I am committed to working on improving the healthcare insurance system for everyone.  This afternoon, Pennsylvania's knowledgeable and impressive Insurance Commissioner, Teresa Miller, is testifying in Washington before the House Democratic Steering and Policy Committee on measures that she believes should be taken to stabilize the health insurance market and scale back premiums and deductibles.

I'm proud to say I won a solid, bipartisan victory in the U.S. House this afternoon, to protect many jobs at Tobyhanna Army Depot and other installations from being outsourced under an antiquated, flawed cost analysis that my amendment prohibits.

There's been no formal declaration, no "day of infamy" speeches, no stirring talk of "we will fight them on the beaches."  But don't be fooled:  we are already at war.  And we need to defend ourselves.

Today marks the 52nd anniversary of the Voting Rights Act of 1965. This legislation, which was signed into law by President Lyndon Johnson, aimed to overcome legal barriers that prevented African Americans from exercising their right to vote. We must continue the fight against obstacles that interfere with any citizen's voting rights, as well and put an end to discrimination.
I am proud to support the Supplemental Nutrition Assistance Program (SNAP) that delivers much-needed assistance to Americans at a precarious point in their lives.

Happy to announce a $52,096 Assistance to Firefighters Grant has been awarded to Diligence Fire Co. No. 1, Summit Hill. The funds are a critical resource to firefighters and communities, I will continue to strongly support this federal program that saves lives.
All right-thinking Americans must condemn racist, anti-Semitic, white supremacist, neo-Nazi thugs.  Our parents and grandparents did, and defeated them.  That's why they were the Greatest Generation.

This month marks the 82nd anniversary of Social Security. Signed into law by President Franklin Roosevelt, this law has provided retirement security to average citizens and their families, as well as income security for workers who become disabled. It is critical that we protect and preserve Social Security – and better update its benefits to the rate of inflation faced by its beneficiaries – in order to safeguard financial stability and a sense of dignity for most Americans.
My thoughts and prayers are with those affected by today's terror attack in Barcelona.

The Clean Water Rule is a commonsense policy that makes clean water a priority throughout the nation. 63% of Pennsylvanians get their drinking water from sources that rely on small streams that are protected by the Clean Water Rule. Eliminating the Clean Water Rule will not only jeopardize access to safe drinking water, but will also threaten public health by compromising the cleanliness and safety of the lakes, rivers, and streams that we use for recreation.  That’s why I have joined more than 100 of my colleagues in opposition to this reckless repeal. http://bit.ly/2ibNkIP
Proud to support our brave firefighters in Monroe County and throughout the 17th District.

When the president fired Steve Bannon, I was hopeful that it marked an acknowledgment of the wrong-headed tack that he took in response to Charlottesville.  But after his remarks in Phoenix, it is clear that the president actually is refusing to retreat from his remarks supportive of racists and neo-Nazis.  Accordingly, I have signed on as a co-sponsor of this Censure resolution.  We expect better of U.S. presidents.

Prayers for everyone in Corpus Christi and southeast Texas facing Hurricane Harvey, with 120+mph winds, 12' flooding, tornadoes, ruined homes, and dangerous flying debris, a horrible natural disaster.

Today we celebrate Women's Equality Day, the 97th anniversary of the 19th Amendment, when the right of women to vote was first guaranteed. We must rededicate ourselves to full access to the ballot box - a fight which remains unfinished today. Join me in the effort to ensure women's equal pay, affordable health and child care, and access to a high-quality education no matter where one lives.

It was an honor to speak at Throop's Hometown Heroes event and to celebrate the 100th birthday of WWII veteran William Kaub. I commend the Throop American Legion, Mayor Frank Andrew Shimkus, the community, families, and volunteers for recognizing the sacrifice, commitment, and dedication demonstrated by the veterans of our community.
As we observe Labor Day, let us pay tribute to the achievements of the labor movement and celebrate the strength and resiliency of the American worker.

We had a good group of about 40 people turn out for yesterday's discussion in Schuylkill Haven. I appreciate people taking the time to come out and give me their input on issues, during a daytime coffee, or at one of our evening Town Halls.

It is always a somber occasion when we gather together on this day every year to remember those who lost their lives on September 11, 2001. As we commemorate those we lost in a terrible act of violence and all the first responders who risked their lives for others, I also hope you will remember the tenacity with which Americans banded together in the days that followed.

I strongly support the Assistance to Firefighters Grant program which helps to ensure firefighters and rescue personnel have the training they need to keep themselves and their communities safe. http://standardspeaker.com/news/mcadoo-fire-receives-grant-1.2240014

I have introduced legislation that will improve orthotics and prosthetics care for service members and veterans. We are challenged to support the grueling recovery process for far too many veterans, and we have a moral obligation to provide our heroes with the best health care available. http://standardspeaker.com/news/cartwright-introduces-vet-bill-1.2241193

I am proud to join the #JobsForAmerica Task Force to create economic growth for working families. I am a co-chair of the Rebuilding America Task Force, which will focus on modernizing our nation’s infrastructure and expanding job opportunities in key industries.   www.dems.gov/jobsforamerica/
I've been named a Co-Chair of the Rebuilding America Task Force in the U.S. House of Representatives.  Our focus will be be on helping create a stronger economy, and better jobs.
I am proud to support federal funding for Head Start; I believe an investment in our children is an investment in the nation's future.
This is a huge piece of the jobs puzzle, and it has already hit our area.  Local employers tell me they have great difficulty finding skilled workers.

If you receive a call from Equifax, please be careful. It is a scam. Equifax will not call you out of the blue. If you have a credit report, there’s a good chance that you’re one of the 143 million American consumers whose sensitive personal information was exposed in a data breach at Equifax. For more information and to make sure you are using a secure site you can go to: https://www.consumer.ftc.gov/blog/2017/09/equifax-data-breach-what-do?
I am part of a group of Republicans and Democrats who understand the importance of developing renewable energy in the United States.

It is my job to represent the 17th congressional district, that is why I continue to have town halls and coffees. I want to thank everyone who came to our town hall, in Tamaqua on Tuesday evening, to talk about the concerns and issues that matter to you. I would like to extend an invitation to everyone for this evenings town hall at the Middle Smithfield Township Building at 6:30pm, hope to see you there.

I was honored to present to a good friend, John Rodgers, his father's distinguished service medals; the American Campaign Medal, Asiatic Pacific Campaign Medal, World War II Victory Medal, Navy Occupation Service Medal, and other military awards and decorations. The gratitude and heartfelt words from Maryellen Rodgers, wife of the late John (Jack) Rodgers, touched everyone present.

The Fort Jenkins Bridge in Pittston is now called the Specialist Dale J. Kridlo Bridge, after the 33-year old member of the 27th Engineer Battalion, 20th Engineer Brigade, XVIII Airborne Corps, who was killed November 7, 2010 in Kunar Province, Afghanistan as part of Operation Enduring Freedom. Here with his parents Michelle Dale and Al Kridlo. Thanks to Pa. Reps. Mike Carroll and Aaron Kaufer for coming up with this bill.
I was pleased to announce the citizens from the 17th Congressional District who will serve on my Health Care/ACA Roundtable.
We honor U.S Representatives Joseph McDade and William Goodling today and extend our deepest condolences to their families.
It was a very moving time to be in the U.S. House this morning as we all stood and clapped and cheered for Steve Scalise, on his courageous return to work!

Proud to announce $118,400 in Economic Impact Initiative and Community Facilities grants for Schuylkill County. These grants will help develop and improve essential public services and facilities in rural communities. http://standardspeaker.com/news/cartwright-announces-schuylkill-grants-1.2248815
My prayers are for the dead and wounded in Las Vegas, and their families.

I was proud to announce another $210,000 in federal money on its way to Wilkes-Barre.  It all goes into our area's economy. http://citizensvoice.com/news/cartwright-announces-210-000-federal-grant-to-wilkes-barre-housing-authority-1.2249186

This morning, I have cosponsored a bill to restrict the sale of "bump stocks."  The bump stock used in Las Vegas helped cause one of the worst mass shooting death tolls in our nation.  I agree with law enforcement that restricting these items is common sense gun safety.
I want to hear from you. How has the ACA affected you and your family? Please share your story with me using the below form.  https://cartwright.house.gov/share-your-aca-story

What a nice time today at the Lions Club Oktoberfest in New Ringgold!  Here with Del Heiser, who in the late 1950s served four years in the US Air Force alongside Carbondale's own 4-star Gen. Jerome F. O'Malley.  Del was accompanied today by his wife Jacque and their daughter Vicki, as we all enjoyed some very good music by Scott Marshall and the Hillbilly Soles!
I serve on the House Oversight Committee, where we had an important hearing with Commerce Secretary Wilbur Ross on the importance of getting the upcoming census right.

My colleague and friend, U.S. Rep. Steve Russell and I spent the afternoon with Lt. Gen. Frederick "Ben" Hodges and the 173rd U.S. Army Airborne observing exercises at Hohenfels, near Nürnberg, Germany.  Gen. Hodges is the commanding general of US Army Europe, and gave Steve and me an extensive update on NATO preparedness.

I met today with Romanian Defense Minister Mihai Fifor (3rd from left) to discuss all aspects of the situation on the southeastern front of the European Union.  With me on the other side of the table (l-r): Cmdr. Bradley Upton, USN, State Dept. Advisor J.J. Fitzgerald, U.S. Rep. Steve Russell (R-Okla), and U.S. Ambassador to Romania Hans Klemm.
Announcing another $6 million on its way to Wilkes-Barre and Luzerne County. I am committed to supporting federal dollars coming back to our area from Washington.

This week as part of our Oversight and Government Reform Committee duties, Rep. Steve Russell (R-Oklahoma City) and I visited with 3-star General Ben Hodges (to my left) and his staff at the 173rd Airborne Brigade's NATO exercises at Hohenfels, Germany. Gen. Hodges gave us a very thorough briefing on current military preparedness in eastern Europe.
I am very happy to report that one of my bills to protect American veterans from predatory scam artists has been passed by the House Veterans Affairs Committee! Hoping for a full House vote soon.
I was proud yesterday to present 7 service decorations, including the Bronze Star Medal and the Combat Infantryman Badge, to Vietnam veteran Lee Umlauf, Ashland, Schuylkill County.

With my strong support, the Da Vinci Science Center recently received a grant from the Economic Development Administration to create a development strategy for their proposed aquarium; this project will enhance the creative economy already thriving in Easton.

Federal programs provide communities with the needed resources to meet the priorities of their neighborhoods; I will continue to work hard to ensure Northeastern Pennsylvania remains in the forefront of securing federal grants.

Our heroes are all around us. Here's World War II veteran Robert Pron, 92, of Cedar Avenue in South Scranton. Bob served in the 15th Air Force in the U.S. Army Air Corps, based near Naples, Italy. He flew 50 missions as radio operator and gunner in a B-24. "I don't know how I made it out of there," he says.

Great day visiting Blakely Hose Company #2 to welcome their newly purchased 2018 custom Marion Pumper. With me from (l-r) are Dennis Pabis, Jim Randelunas, Deputy Chief Kevin Kearney, Lt. David Kobierecki, Tony Cardell, Joe Quinn, and Asst. Boro Manager Chris Paone. I continue to support maintaining Rural Development grants that help to fund these projects.
Starting today, explore your health coverage options for 2018. Last year, 8 in 10 people qualified for financial help. Visit www.HealthCare.gov to find a plan that best fits your budget and needs.

Proud to report that the House Oversight and Government Reform Committee unanimously passed my PREPARE Act today. This bipartisan, zero-cost bill would enhance government preparedness for extreme weather events. It’s a commonsense bill that would save lives & taxpayer dollars.  https://cartwright.house.gov/media-center/press-releases/cartwright-lance-applaud-committee-passage-of-bipartisan-prepare-act

Thank you Lt.-Cmdr. Michael Boettcher, Cmdr. Christine Bailer, and Training Officer Dave Hudzinski for inviting me to tour your exceptional facility; the Navy Operational Support Center in Avoca, PA. We are so lucky to have this facility right here in Northeastern Pennsylvania. I was honored to recognize a bright young member of our community, Chief Petty Officer Anthony DeMark, Division Chief for the Wahoo Division of the Sea Cadets. If Anthony is indicative of his generation, we are in very good hands.

I wanted to share with everyone a letter that an old school friend of mine, John Christopher, a lifelong Republican, wrote to House Speaker Paul Ryan, regarding the GOP tax plan, a 400+ page bill going through final committee amendments today, 4 days after introduction, without any hearings at all. We'll see what the final product is, but in the meantime, I couldn't agree more with John Christopher's comments:  Dear Speaker Ryan: I have been a member of the Republican party since my first vote in the 1980 presidential election. In 2012, I supported you as the best hope of our party and our nation. I believed you understood basic economics, and had the best interests of our country at heart. Your latest tax "reform" bill leaves me wondering what has become of my party. First, your so-called "reform" adds trillions of dollars to the federal debt my children and their children will have to pay off. Second, your so-called "reform" imposes substantial additional burdens on tax payers in the states that place the highest value on maintaining strong systems of public education. By double taxing our state and local tax payments, we shoulder the biggest burden of the cost of your so-called "reform". Third, by eliminating the state and local tax deduction, your so-called "reform" makes it significantly more difficult for individuals to itemize deductions. In fact, the bill estimates that nearly 25% of Americans will stop itemizing their deductions under this bill. A recent study conducted by Indiana University estimates that if your so-called "reform" becomes the law, charitable giving is likely to decline by more than $13 billion in the first year alone! Fourth, despite the smoke and mirrors of doing tax returns on a postcard and reducing brackets from 7 to 4, this cannot disguise the fact that you are INCREASING the tax rate from 10-12% (a 20% INCREASE on the lowest income taxpayers (those joint filers earning up to $18,650 over the standard deduction and those single filers earning up to $9,325 over the standard deduction). At the same time, the highest wage earners receive significant reductions in their tax rates. IN WHAT UNIVERSE CAN OUR REPUBLICAN PARTY POSSIBLY JUSTIFY THIS OR EXPECT THESE LOW INCOME PERSONS TO FOOT THIS INCREASED BURDEN? There are so many things that are wrong with this bill, and so very little that comports with the ideals that were once at the core of our party. If this is where the party is now, you can count me out! Sincerely, John Christopher
Praying for the injured Pennsylvania state trooper and his family. I am closely monitoring this situation.  http://www.mcall.com/news/breaking/mc-nws-route-33-shooting-20171107-story.html

Proud to announce that my bill, H.R. 3122 - the Veterans Care Financial Protection Act, passed the U.S. House of Representatives this week.  In my district and across the country, there are scam artists who take advantage of older veterans. This bill is a bipartisan, commonsense proposal that would protect veterans from these predatory practices. We owe this to our nation’s heroes.  https://cartwright.house.gov/media-center/press-releases/house-passes-cartwright-s-bipartisan-bill-to-protect-veterans
It's hard to explain how difficult it is these days to pass a bill in Congress.  So passing one like this was a thrill.

I want to thank Vice-Pres. Jim Davenport and the Dunmore Rotary Club for inviting me to the unveiling of the WWI Memorial in Dunmore to commemorate the 262 soldiers from Lackawanna County who died during the Great War. Their sacrifices are part of the reason why we have the freedoms we have today. We owe our servicemen and women a debt of gratitude and respect; respect for this group of Americans can never be undone. It was nice to be joined by so many including Senator John P. Blake and Commissioner Pat O'Malley.

Today, I spoke on the House floor about how the tax reform bill will ship jobs overseas and leave Pennsylvania working families behind. Here is just one story of how many lives are affected by these harmful offshoring practices.
On behalf of all of us here in the congressional office, please accept our best wishes for a joyful and peaceful Thanksgiving holiday!
Happy to be asked to appear on The Volpe Report, Sunday, November 26 at 10:30 a.m. on Fox56. Tune in tomorrow to hear us talk about trade, taxes, and bipartisanship.

I was honored to participate in the Eagle Scout Court of Honor for Troop 316 in Avoca, PA. Congratulations to Noah Jennings, Senior Patrol Leader and Charlie Vermac, Assistant Senior Patrol Leader on receiving the distinguished Eagle Scout Award; the Eagle is the highest recognition that Scouting offers to Scouts. You both deserve much credit and are an example to your fellow Scouts.

It was great to meet MAJ Mary Anczarski, PA-C, USAR from Shenandoah, Schuylkill County today. MAJ Anczarski is an Army medic and currently serving in Arlington, Virginia. I am thankful for her service and the service of so many others.

On December 12, 1787, delegates to the Pennsylvania ratifying convention meeting at the Pennsylvania State House (now known as Independence Hall) voted to ratify the Constitution of the United States.
Wishing everyone a Happy Hanukkah filled with the joy of spending holiday time surrounded with loved ones.

Congratulations to my friend Doug Jones, the new junior Senator-elect from Alabama. You may not know his background. Here we are a couple years ago in Birmingham, Alabama, in front of the famous 16th Street Baptist Church, which was bombed 3 weeks after the March on Washington and MLK's "I have a dream" speech. On September 15, 1963, four little girls, Addie Mae Collins, Carole Robertson, Cynthia Wesley and Denise McNair, were here for choir practice.  When the bomb exploded, all 4 died inside the church. Doug Jones was the US Attorney for the Northern District of Alabama, and successfully prosecuted the cold-case murder trial of two of the bombers, Bobby Cherry and Thomas Blanton, 38 years later. Each was found guilty on four counts of first-degree murder. Doug also successfully prosecuted the notorious fugitive Atlanta Olympics bomber, Eric Rudolph. I'm thrilled to welcome Doug to Capitol Hill.
I continue to be concerned about the safety of our corrections officers in the federal prisons. Overcrowding and understaffing is a dangerous combination for everyone.

Is there hope for a real fix? I’d like to think so. Earlier this month, I cosponsored a bill authored by Rep. Stephanie Murphy, a Florida Democrat, to fund CHIP for five years, paid for by efficiency improvements to federal health care payments and with no change to Medicare premiums for seniors.

Today, regrettably, the Federal Communications Commission voted to damage and roll back net neutrality.  I think this issue is important enough that Congress needs to address it.  Congress needs to take up the matter and put it to a vote, and not leave it up to unelected officials of the FCC.  I support protecting net neutrality, and establishing clear and fair rules for everyone.

One of my very good friends in the U.S. House is Congressman Mike Thompson, a decorated Vietnam veteran and a member of the Ways and Means Committee, which writes the tax laws.    Mike gave a speech this week about the proposed tax bill that I hope you will read.  I agree with Mike.  Here is what he said:   “I’m Congressman Mike Thompson.  I represent California’s 5th Congressional District, and I’m a Member of the House Committee on Ways and Means, the tax-writing committee.   “This week, Republicans continued to push their tax bill that would devastate middle class and working Americans, and explode our national debt.  This bill was written without the benefit of any hearings, any testimony from expert witnesses or any input from Democrats.   “The bill is written to give massive, permanent tax breaks to the rich and to corporate interests, many of which ship U.S. jobs overseas.  It does give a handful of temporary tax cuts to some middle class taxpayers, but actually raises taxes on millions of middle and working class families.   “An overwhelming majority of these tax breaks go to the top 1 percent of the richest Americans.   “The Republicans take away important tax provisions that so many middle class families rely on to make ends meet.  And it’s not just middle class families that will be hurt by the repeal of these provisions.  Seniors, disabled Americans and veterans all count on various tax provisions that are now on the chopping block, effectively raising their taxes.   “As a Vietnam veteran and supporter of our veterans, I find any legislation that would hurt our country’s heroes to be particularly disgraceful.  Our first responders also get a raw deal under this plan.   “Republicans want to roll back the State and Local Tax Deduction – an important provision that funds vital, local government services like police and fire.  It’s shameful that they want to dismantle this deduction that will hurt law enforcement and firefighters so they can give tax breaks to folks who really don’t need them.   “The Republicans’ bill also undermines the Affordable Care Act, taking health care away from 13 million Americans and raising premiums by 10 percent for everyone else.  And the Republican plan adds a shocking $2.3 trillion to our already sky-high national debt, just to pay for these tax breaks for corporations and the very richest Americans.  That means our kids and grandkids will be left to pay the bill.   “To add insult to injury, the Republican leadership has stated they will cut Social Security, Medicare, veterans’ benefits and other critical government services because the debt is too high.  That’s just wrong.   “Democrats believe that our country needs real tax reform, but this is not tax reform.  What the Republicans’ bill does is shift important tax benefits from middle class and working families to the rich and to corporate interests.  That’s wildly irresponsible.   “Democrats have been working from an agenda that’s focused on strengthening and expanding the middle class. We call it ‘A Better Deal.’  As part of that Better Deal, we believe that meaningful tax reform must begin and end with middle class families, it shouldn’t be built on their backs.   “The American people deserve a fair tax code that leads to better jobs, better wages, and a better future that gives everyone a chance to realize the American dream.  That means putting hard-working, middle-class families ahead of the richest among us, and building a tax code that allows small businesses and innovators to thrive.   “Democrats are calling on Republicans to drop this wrong-headed bill and work with us on real tax reform.  With something this big, it cannot and should not be jammed through Congress by one party alone.   “Thank you.”

We had an enjoyable holiday party at the Gino Merli Veterans Center this morning. Thanks to sponsor Matt McGloin! Here with WWII Veteran Herm Breuninger, 92, of Dunmore, Gunner's Mate on various ships in the Pacific Theater.  He enlisted in 1942 at age 17 and soon saw action at Guadalcanal, one of heaviest casualty tolls in U.S. Navy history. The Japanese sunk so many of our ships there it became known as Iron Bottom Sound.  "I saw 600 dead sailors there," Herm told me.

"These are the times that try men's souls." -- Thomas Paine.  It's hard to be in the minority and watch as Medicare gets cut, healthcare gets sabotaged, offshoring jobs gets rewarded, money that should be spent on American infrastructure and lowering prescription drug prices instead gets spent on tax cuts that mostly go to people who don't need them, 86 million middle class families see their taxes go up, and the national debt goes up by $1.4 Trillion, paving the way for even more cuts to Social Security, Medicare and Medicaid. Elections have consequences.

I am happy to announce the FY2017 Assistance to Firefighters Grants application period opens Tuesday, December 26 at 8 AM. It closes Friday, February 2, 2018 at 5 PM. Ensuring first responders have reliable, up-to-date equipment should be one of our highest national priorities. That’s why I support programs like the AFG that help our cash-strapped communities keep people and property safe.  Please contact my office for assistance and advice on applying for these grants!
Wishing you all the joys and blessings of the Christmas season.
I was happy to announce that federal funding is on its way to Luzerne County Head Start. Head Start and Early Head Start programs are an important investment in our community and our economy.
